title: Lady Gaga releasing Artpop without R Kelly song after sexual abuse claims
text:
Lady Gaga has distanced herself from R Kelly this year (Picture: WireImage)

Lady Gaga has decided to re-release her 2013 album Artpop but it won’t feature her now-controversial collaboration with R Kelly.

The Born This Way singer has made physical copies of Artpop available for pre-order on HMV’s website so fans can purchase CD and vinyl versions.

Fans will be able to cop the new version from 11 November, more than six years after the album’s original release date on 6 November 2013.

But one song will be noticeably missing – it appears Gaga’s collaboration with R Kelly on Do What U Want (With My Body) has been removed from the tracklist, while all the other songs are still included.

It comes after Gaga, 33, apologised for collaborating with R Kelly on the song in light of the multiple sexual allegations against him.

Back in January, the popstar released a lengthy statement denouncing the disgraced R&B singer following the release of Surviving R Kelly, the harrowing documentary which featured accounts from his alleged sexual abuse victims.

Gaga captioned the statement which was published on Twitter: ‘I stand by anyone who has ever been the victim of sexual assault.’

The pair’s performance on SNL was a controversial one (Picture: Getty Images)

In the message, the singer explained: ‘I stand behind these women 1000%, believe them, know they are suffering and in pain, and feel strongly that their voices should be heard and taken seriously.

‘What I am hearing about the allegations against R Kelly is absolutely horrifying and indefensible. As a victim of sexual assault myself, I made both the song and video at a dark time in my life, my intention was to create something extremely defiant and provocative because I was angry and still hadn’t processed the trauma that had occurred in my own life.’

Addressing the controversial title of the song, Gaga stated: ‘The song is called Do What U Want (With My Body), I think it’s clear how explicitly twisted my thinking was at the time.

I stand by anyone who has ever been the victim of sexual assault: pic.twitter.com/67sz4WpV3i — Lady Gaga (@ladygaga) January 10, 2019

‘If I could go back and have a talk with my younger self I’d tell her to go through the therapy I have since then, so that I could understand the confused post-traumatic state that I was in – or if therapy was not available to me or anyone in my situation – to seek help, and speak as openly and honestly as possible about what we’ve been through.’

Hinting at her future plans to distance herself from the song, Gaga concluded: ‘I intend to remove this song off of iTunes and other streaming platforms and will not be working with him again.’

The song earned criticism long before the recent allegations against R Kelly surfaced.

The musicians performed the song together on Saturday Night Live at the time of its release and received criticism for the uncomfortable sexual nature of the performance, with Gaga straddling the disgraced singer on-stage.
